21:15 <CameronE> has joined #xwiki  
21:26 <CameronE> Hi all; I'm setting up XWiki from scratch, to act as an internal knowledge base for the technical support team with which I work.  Because I'm starting from scratch, I can easily choose the underlying platform.  Are there any notable (perhaps speed, ease of administration or reliability?) advantages to going with Linux server vs a Windows one for XWiki?  To start, I tried the Windows .EXE but don't feel great about Jetty, since it's   
21:32 <cjd> don't feel great about Jetty, since it's|<-- you were cut off  
21:37 <cjd> To answer your question, linux is much better than windows because all things todo with servers have 99% of all testing done on linux, XWiki included.  
21:38 <CameronE> continuing where I got cut off: "since it's a web server I'd never heard of."  
21:38 <cjd> ahh, jetty is actually a nice little webserver  
21:38 <CameronE> I'm glad to hear that XWiki gets more testing done on Linux servers  
21:38 <cjd> most of the problems I find are related to tomcat which everybody uses  
21:39 <CameronE> Hmm...if I go with Linux, would you advise using a different container?  
21:39 <cjd> Everything does, all of the XWiki SAS production buildouts are based on linux and for production you just want to go with what people use.  
21:39 <CameronE> Indeed.  That's exactly what I needed to know.  
21:40 <CameronE> Was my instinct, but then again, where I work, we host everything on Windows  
21:40 <CameronE> (not my choice)  
21:40 <cjd> Everybody likes tomcat, I personally think jetty is a fine and capable server.  
21:40 <CameronE> OK; The volume on this thing isn't going to be super-high.  
21:40 <CameronE> Since it's an internal KB  
21:41 <CameronE> Would you say Jetty is likely to be more reliable / cause fewer issues for me than tomcat?  
21:41 <cjd> My personal favorite setup is to take the default XWiki .zip which is available on the downloads page, unzip it and edit hibernate.cfg.xml to change it to use mysql  
21:41 <CameronE> ok; was planning to use mysql  
21:42 <cjd> Jetty is nice because it's packaged with XWiki, we develop with it and run the automated tests on the CI server with it.  
21:42 <CameronE> great.  since I work in tech support myself  
21:42 <cjd> We run production on Tomcat instances because that's what people use...  
21:42 <CameronE> I see all of the problems that come from untested combos  
21:42 <cjd> But then my personal feeling is that Tomcat is "just one more thing to maintain"  
21:43 <CameronE> and I want one thing less to maintain  
21:43 <CameronE> longer-term would I need to do anything in particular to the mysql db?  
21:43 <CameronE> (to maintain)  
21:43 <cjd> unless of course you're running a dozen other sites on a Tomcat instance and you want everything together.  
21:43 <CameronE> right; my setup will be simple and serving 30ish people  
21:43 <cjd> If you're going to be doing a lot of (large) attachments you might check out Filesystem Attachments  
21:44 <cjd> it's much easier to go ahead and do that right away than it is to migrate to it  
21:44 <CameronE> I will consider that.  
21:44 <CameronE> Will be mostly screen shots  
21:44 <CameronE> so guessing that might not be necessary  
21:44 <cjd> If you decide you want to keep attachments in the db, you'll want to increase mysql max\_packet\_size  
21:45 <cjd> I think this is in the installation instructions  
21:45 <CameronE> ah - ok.  I should probably go with fs attachments then; didn't realize by default it would keep files in the db  
21:45 <CameronE> Alright; sounds like I've got some work cut out for me.  Was nice to try the EXE and immediately get it set up more or less as POC  
21:46 <CameronE> But I'll feel solid with it on Linux longer-term.  Will go with Jetty.  
21:46 <cjd> yeah  
21:46 <CameronE> It's Ubuntu and I could install the .deb's, but I get the sense it'll be better to do the manual install  
21:47 <cjd> It's hard for me to say, they tell me the .debs work very well but I have been around since before they started being made so I tend to use the .zip  
21:47 <CameronE> ok; then I'll try with the .debs first  
21:47 <CameronE> Upgrading generally OK with .debs too?  
21:48 <CameronE> (for later)  
21:48 <cjd> upgrading can be a pain depending on how heavily you modify the wiki  
21:48 <cjd> as in how much scripting you do  
21:48 <CameronE> will be little scripting  
21:49 <CameronE> most I plan on is to have a query on one page to show the articles with the most ancient updates  
21:49 <CameronE> so we can keep the info up to date  
21:49 <cjd> first you upgrade the wiki engine itself then you have to upgrade the default pages in the wiki  
21:49 <cjd> Extension Manager helps with this but the technology is a bit new  
21:49 <CameronE> hmm; well if you think it's not any worse starting with the .debs...  
21:49 <CameronE> I'll cross the upgrade bridge once we get there  
21:50 <cjd> yeah, we end up with some ugly upgrade stories... but we also have a lot of wikis which are so heavily modded that they don't even look like XWiki anymore  
21:51 <CameronE> Yes, very flexible product, so I'm sure.  Mine will definitely stay as a normal wiki.  
21:51 <CameronE> And I'll absolutely make sure to back up all the files and the db before touching a thing.  
21:51 <cjd> so take it as you will.. I think for a simple wiki, the upgrade should be pretty easy but I don't want to mislead you if you end up spending a few hours on it  
21:51 <CameronE> Point well taken.
